front.title: Multiplexing Negotiation Using Session Description Protocol (SDP) Port Numbers

abstract.t: This specification defines a new SDP Grouping Framework SDP grouping framework extension, "BUNDLE" and "USE-BUNDLE", that can be used with the Session Description Protocol (SDP) Offer/Answer mechanism to negotiate the usage of bundled media, which refers to the usage of a single 5-tuple transport flow for media associated with multiple SDP media descriptions ("m=" lines).

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In the IETF RTCWEB WG, a need to use a single 5-tuple for sending and receiving media associated with multiple SDP media descriptions ("m=" lines) has been identified. This would e.g. allow the usage of a single set of Interactive Connectivity Establishment (ICE) candidates for multiple media descriptions. Normally different media types (audio, video etc) will be described using different media descriptions.

This specification defines two new SDP Grouping Framework SDP grouping framework extension, "BUNDLE" and "USE-BUNDLE", that can be used with the Session Description Protocol (SDP) Offer/Answer mechanism to negotiate the usage of bundled media, which refers to the usage of a single 5-tuple transport flow for media associated with multiple SDP media descriptions ("m=" lines).

When an endpoint generates an SDP Offer , which includes a "BUNDLE" group, the endpoint is indicating that it is willing to have each "m=" line associated with the group end up using a single transport port if bundle is negotiated.
When an endpoint generates an SDP Answer , which includes a "USE-BUNDLE" group, each "m=" line associated with the group will end up using a single transport port.

As defined in RFC 4566 , the semantics of multiple "m=" lines using the same port number value are undefined, and there is no grouping defined by such means. Instead, an explicit grouping mechanism needs to be used to express the intended semantics. This specification provides such extension.

When media is transported using the Real-Time Protocol (RTP) , the default assumption of the mechanism is that all media associated with a "BUNDLE" group will form a single RTP Session . However, future specifications can extend the mechanism, in order to negotiate RTP Session multiplexing, i.e. "BUNDLE" groups where media associated with a group form multiple RTP Sessions.

The mechanism is backward compatible. Entities that do not support the "BUNDLE" grouping extension, or do not want to enable the mechanism for a given session, are expected to generate a "normal" SDP Offer and Answer, using different port number values for each "m=" line, to the SDP Offer.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .
5-tuple: A collection of the following values: source IP address, source transport port, destination IP address, destination transport port and transport protocol.

Bundled media: Two or more RTP streams using a single 5-tuple. The RTCP streams associated with the RTP streams also use a single 5-tuple, which might be the same, but can also be different, as the one used by the RTP streams.

section.title: Applicability Statement
section.t: The mechanism in this specification only applies to the Session Description Protocol (SDP) , when used together with the SDP Offer/Answer mechanism .

section.title: SDP Grouping Framework BUNDLE Extension Semantics
section.t: This section defines a new SDP Grouping Framework extension, "BUNDLE".

The "BUNDLE" extension in an SDP Offer can be indicated using an SDP session-level 'group' attribute. Each SDP media description ("m=" line) that is grouped together, using an SDP media-level 'mid' attribute, is part of a specific "BUNDLE" group.

section.title: SDP Grouping Framework USE-BUNDLE Extension Semantics
section.t: This section defines a new SDP Grouping Framework extension, "USE-BUNDLE".

The "USE-BUNDLE" extension in an SDP Answer can be indicated using an SDP session-level 'group' attribute. Each SDP media description ("m=" line) that is grouped together, using an SDP media-level 'mid' attribute, is part of a specific "USE-BUNDLE" group. The 5-tuple used is the one formed by the transport information from the mid of the first entry in the BUNDLE group and the first entry of the USE-BUNDLE group.

section.title: General
section.t: When an SDP Offerer or SDP Answerer generates an SDP Offer or SDP Answer, that describes bundled media, it MUST insert an SDP session-level 'group' attribute, with a "BUNDLE" value for Offers or a "USE-BUNDLE" for answers, and assign SDP media-level 'mid' attribute values to each "m=" line associated with the group.

In addition, the entity that generates the SDP Offer MUST also generate the rest of the offer in roughly the same ways as if it did not support BUNDLE. For each "m=" line that is part of the "BUNDLE" group:

list.t: Use a different port number value.
Use the same connection data ("c=" line) value.
Use a different port for each SDP 'rtcp' attribute value, when 'rtcp' attribute is used.
Use ICE candidate values with different ports and values, when ICE is used.
Insert and support an SDP 'rtpc-mux' attribute.
Use the same DTLS-SRTP fingerprint attribute, when DTLS-SRTP is used
Use different SDES crypto attribute, when SDES is used

section.t: There are also special rules for handling many different attributes as defined in TODO [draft-nandakumar-rtcweb-sdp-attribute-analysis]. It is not possible to use bundle with some attributes.

section.title: SDP Offerer Procedures
section.t: When an SDP Offerer creates an SDP Offer, that offers bundled media, it MUST create the SDP Offer according to the procedures in .

If the associated SDP Answer contains an SDP session-level 'group' attribute, with a "USE-BUNDLE" value, the SDP Offerer can start using the 5-tuple of the first "m=" line in the group for sending and receiving media for all the "m=" lines in the group.
If the SDP Answer does not include a session-level SDP 'group' attribute, with a "USE-BUNDLE" value, the SDP Offerer cannot use the same 5-tuple for media associated with multiple "m=" lines.
If the SDP Answer indicates that it will not use bundled media, SDP usage work in the same way as if BUNLE had not been used.

section.title: SDP Answerer Procedures
section.t: When an SDP Answerer receives an SDP Offer, which offers bundled media, and the SDP Answerer accepts the offered bundle group. Any "m=" lines that are rejected have their port set to zero as usual. Any "m=" lines that are not rejected have the port on the "m=" line, as well as the ICE, 'rtcp' attribute, 'rtcp-mux' and ICE attributes set to the value to be used by the single 5-tuple over which all the media in the group will use.

If the SDP Answerer does not accept the "BUNDLE" group in the SDP Offer, it MUST NOT include a session level 'group' attribute, with a "BUNDLE" or "USE-BUNDLE" value, in the associated SDP Answer. In addition, the SDP Answerer MUST provide separate port number values for each "m=" line of the SDP Answer and separate ICE atribute values.

section.title: General
section.t: When entities negotiate the usage of bundled media, the default assumption is that all media associated with the bundled media will form a single RTP session.

The usage of multiple RTP Sessions within a "BUNDLE" group is outside the scope of this specification. Other specification needs to extend the mechanism in order to allow negotiation of such bundle groups.

section.title: Single RTP Session
section.t: When a single RTP Session is used, media associated with all "m=" lines part of a bundle group share a single SSRC numbering space.
In addition, the following rules and restrictions apply for a single RTP Session:

list.t: - The dynamic payload type values used in the "m=" lines MUST NOT overlap.
- The "proto" value in each "m=" line MUST be identical (e.g. RTP/AVPF).
- A given SSRC SHOULD NOT transmit RTP packets using payload types that originates from different "m=" lines.

section.t: NOTE: The last bullet above is to avoid sending multiple media types from the same SSRC. If transmission of multiple media types are done with time overlap RTP and RTCP fails to function. Even if done in proper sequence this causes RTP Timestamp rate switching issues [ref to draft-ietf-avtext-multiple-clock-rates].

section.title: General
section.t: This section describes how to use the "BUNDLE" grouping mechanism together with the Interactive Connectivity Establishment (ICE) mechanism .

section.title: Candidates
section.t: When an ICE-enabled SDP Offerer sends an initial SDP offer, it MUST include ICE candidates for each "m=" line associated with a "BUNDLE" group. The candidate values MUST be different for each "m=" line associated with the group. This rule does not apply to subsequent SDP Offers, when the usage of bundled media has already been negotiated.

When an ICE-enabled SDP Answerer receives an SDP Offer, offering a "BUNDLE" group and ICE, if the SDP Answerer enables ICE, it MUST include ICE candidates for each "m=" line of the SDP Answer. This also applies for "m=" lines that are part of a "USE-BUNDLE" group, in which case the candidate values MUST be the same for each "m=" line associated with the group. This rule applies also to subsequent SDP Answers, when the usage of bundled media has already been negotiated.

Once the usage of bundled media has been negotiated, ICE connectivity checks and keep-alives only needs to be performed for the 5-tuple used by the "USE-BUNDLE" group, instead of for each individual m= line associated with the group.

section.title: Example
section.t: The example below shows an SDP Offer, where bundled media is offered. The example also shows two SDP Answer alternatives: one where bundled media is accepted, and one where bundled media is rejected (or, not even supported) by the SDP Answerer.

figure.artwork:
SDP Offer (Bundled media offered)
v=0 o=alice 2890844526 2890844526 IN IP4 host.atlanta.com s= c=IN IP4 host.atlanta.com t=0 0 a=group:BUNDLE foo bar m=audio 10000 RTP/AVP 0 8 97 a=mid:foo b=AS:200 a=rtpmap:0 PCMU/8000 a=rtpmap:8 PCMA/8000 a=rtpmap:97 iLBC/8000 m=video 10002 RTP/AVP 31 32 a=mid:bar b=AS:1000 a=rtpmap:31 H261/90000 a=rtpmap:32 MPV/90000

SDP Answer (Bundled media accepted)
v=0 o=bob 2808844564 2808844564 IN IP4 host.biloxi.com s= c=IN IP4 host.biloxi.com t=0 0 a=group:USE-BUNDLE foo bar m=audio 20000 RTP/AVP 0 a=mid:foo b=AS:200 a=rtpmap:0 PCMU/8000 m=video 20000 RTP/AVP 32 a=mid:bar b=AS:1000 a=rtpmap:32 MPV/90000

SDP Answer (Bundled media not accepted)
v=0 o=bob 2808844564 2808844564 IN IP4 host.biloxi.com s= c=IN IP4 host.biloxi.com t=0 0 m=audio 20000 RTP/AVP 0 b=AS:200 a=rtpmap:0 PCMU/8000 m=video 30000 RTP/AVP 32 b=AS:1000 a=rtpmap:32 MPV/90000

SDP Offer with ICE (Bundled media offered)
v=0 o=alice 2890844526 2890844526 IN IP4 host.atlanta.com s= c=IN IP4 host.atlanta.com t=0 0 a=group:BUNDLE foo bar m=audio 10000 RTP/AVP 0 8 97 a=mid:foo b=AS:200 a=rtpmap:0 PCMU/8000 a=rtpmap:8 PCMA/8000 a=rtpmap:97 iLBC/8000 a=candidate:1 1 UDP 1694498815 host.atlanta.com 10000 typ host m=video 10002 RTP/AVP 31 32 a=mid:bar b=AS:1000 a=rtpmap:31 H261/90000 a=rtpmap:32 MPV/90000 a=candidate:1 1 UDP 1694498815 host.atlanta.com 10002 typ host

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document requests IANA to register the new SDP Grouping semantic extension called BUNDLE and USE-BUNDLE.

section.title: Acknowledgements
section.t: The usage of the SDP grouping mechanism is based on a similar alternative proposed by Harald Alvestrand. The SDP examples are also modified versions from the ones in the Alvestrand proposal.
